TAGI-V
AGVI & TAGI-V theory and implementation.
Sep 13, 2024
•
5 min read

Bayesian neural networks (BNNs) offer a probabilistic approach to estimate the modelâ€™s confidence in both its parameters and predictions. However, performing exact Bayesian Inference is NP-hard1, making it computationally intractable.

Tractable Approximate Gaussian Inference (TAGI) distinguishes itself from other methods by enabling BNNs to perform analytical parameter inference with O(n)O(n)O(n) computational complexity, where nnn is the number of parameters2. But TAGI in its current form can only model homoscedastic aleatory uncertainty that is quantified by a constant error variance across the input covariate domain.

Deka et al. developed the Approximate Gaussian Variance Inference (AGVI), which enables analytical inference of the error variance term as a Gaussian random variable3. In this context, TAGIâ€‘V combines TAGI and AGVI to allow the modeling of heteroscedastic aleatory uncertainty in BNNs4.

In this article we will see how AGVI works and how to apply it on TAGI, resulting in TAGIâ€‘V. Then we will go through the implementation of TAGIâ€‘V in the cuTAGI5 open source library. In case you donâ€™t know about TAGI, go check the last blog where we explain step by step this method.

AGVI

The core idea of Approximate Gaussian Variance Inference (AGVI) is to lift the constant error variance in TAGI into a full Gaussian random variable that can adapt per input. AGVI proceeds in two main steps:

  1. Prior via Gaussian Multiplicative Approximation (GMA)
    We begin by modeling the squared error V2V^2V2 as a Gaussian:

    f(v2)=N(v2;â€‰Î¼V2,â€‰ÏƒV22)withÏƒV22=2â€‰Î¼V22.f(v^2) = \mathcal{N}\bigl(v^2;\,\mu_{V^2},\,\sigma^2_{V^2}\bigr) \quad\text{with}\quad \sigma^2_{V^2} = 2\,\mu_{V^2}^2.f(v2)=N(v2;Î¼V2â€‹,ÏƒV22â€‹)withÏƒV22â€‹=2Î¼V22â€‹.

    Since VVV itself is zeroâ€“mean, its variance equals E[V2]=Î¼V2\mathbb{E}[V^2] = \mu_{V^2}E[V2]=Î¼V2â€‹, giving

    f(v)=N(v;0,Î¼V2),f(v)=\mathcal{N}(v;0,\mu_{V^2}),f(v)=N(v;0,Î¼V2â€‹),

    and by treating Î¼V2\mu_{V^2}Î¼V2â€‹ as a Gaussian random variable, we preserve analytical tractability.

  2. Posterior update via Gaussian conditioning
    Once the networkâ€™s predictive distribution for the error VVV is available through the TAGI inference pass, we update our belief on ÏƒV2\sigma^2_VÏƒV2â€‹ by conditioning on the observed residuals. Concretely, if the prior on V2V^2V2 is N(Î¼V2,â€‰2Î¼V22)\mathcal{N}(\mu_{V^2},\,2\mu_{V^2}^2)N(Î¼V2â€‹,2Î¼V22â€‹) and the posterior on VVV yields a mean-zero Gaussian with variance Ïƒ^V2\hat\sigma_V^2Ïƒ^V2â€‹, then the posterior moments of V2V^2V2 follow directly from standard Gaussian conditional formulas.

By iterating these two stepsâ€”forward propagation of moments for both the main output and the variance head, and backward conditioningâ€”we obtain closedâ€‘form updates for both the network parameters and the inputâ€‘dependent noise variance.

Heteroscedasticity

In uncertainty quantification, homoscedastic aleatory uncertainty assumes a single noise level for all inputs,

y=z(O)+v,vâˆ¼N(0,ÏƒV2),y = z^{(\mathrm{O})} + v,\quad v\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma_V^2),y=z(O)+v,vâˆ¼N(0,ÏƒV2â€‹),

where ÏƒV2\sigma_V^2ÏƒV2â€‹ is fixed2. While simple, this fails to capture cases where data noise naturally varies across the domain.

By contrast, heteroscedastic uncertainty allows ÏƒV2\sigma_V^2ÏƒV2â€‹ to depend on the input x\mathbf{x}x:

y=z(O)(x)+v,vâˆ¼N(0,ÏƒV2(x)).y = z^{(\mathrm{O})}(\mathbf{x}) + v,\quad v\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma_V^2(\mathbf{x})).y=z(O)(x)+v,vâˆ¼N(0,ÏƒV2â€‹(x)).

Modeling ÏƒV2(x)\sigma_V^2(\mathbf{x})ÏƒV2â€‹(x) is crucial when different regions of the input space exhibit different noise levelsâ€”e.g., sensor readings with conditionâ€‘dependent precision. AGVI equips TAGI with exactly this capability by inferring ÏƒV2\sigma_V^2ÏƒV2â€‹ analytically rather than tuning it as a hyperparameter.

TAGIâ€‘V

TAGIâ€‘V seamlessly integrates TAGIâ€™s analytic parameter inference with AGVIâ€™s variance inference, yielding a fully closedâ€‘form, heteroscedastic Bayesian neural network.

  • Dualâ€‘head architecture: Each network outputs both

    z(O)andVË‰2,z^{(\mathrm{O})}\quad\text{and}\quad \bar V^2,z(O)andVË‰2,

    where VË‰2\bar V^2VË‰2 is the networkâ€™s prediction of the local noise variance.

  • Computational complexity: TAGIâ€‘V retains the O(n)O(n)O(n) scaling in the number of parameters nnn of original TAGI, thanks to GMA and layerâ€‘wise recursion.

  • Empirical performance: On standard regression benchmarks, TAGIâ€‘V delivers superior test logâ€‘likelihood compared to homoscedastic TAGI and matches or outperforms other approximate inference methodsâ€”while being an order of magnitude faster.

TAGIâ€‘V in cuTAGI

The cuTAGI library provides a CUDAâ€‘accelerated implementation of both TAGI and TAGIâ€‘V:

  • Output layout
    In cuTAGIâ€™s implementation, the final layerâ€™s tensor is of size 2Y2Y2Y. Even indices hold the predictive means z(O)z^{(\mathrm{O})}z(O), and odd indices hold the variance head VË‰2\bar V^2VË‰2. Internally, cuTAGI splits this tensor and runs two parallel TAGI inference tracks: one for the mean and one for the variance.

  • API usage

    net = Sequential(
      Linear(1, 128),
      ReLU(),
      Linear(128, 128),
      ReLU(),
      Linear(128, 1*2), # Double of inputs
      EvenExp(),        # Exponential for V2_bar
)

# ...

# Testing
for x, y in test_batch_iter:
      # Predicion
      m_pred, v_pred = net(x)

      # Even positions correspond to Z_out and odd positions to V
      var_preds.extend(v_pred[::2] + m_pred[1::2])

      mu_preds.extend(m_pred[::2])

      x_test.extend(x)
      y_test.extend(y)
